description.narrative: Output Based Aid "kuponger" för mödravård som subventionerar kostnaden för gravida kvinnor och nyblivna mödrar till kvalitativ hälsovård. Programmet genonförs i samarbete med Världsbanken

Output Based Aid voucher programme for maternal care to subsidy the cost of access to quality ante-natal, maternal and post-natal care for pregnant and newly delivered mothers and their babies. The project is implemented in cooperation with the World Bank GPOBA.

The Uganda Reproductive Health Voucher Project (URHVP) was a four-year program (2015-2019) implemented by Marie Stopes Uganda (MSU) on behalf of the ministry of Health, in 25 districts of South-western and Eastern Uganda.
The main development objective of the project was to increase access to safe delivery services for marginalized women living in rural and disadvantaged areas during pregnancy and delivery.

participating-org.narrative: IBRD/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank
IBRD/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
As concluded in the final semi-annual report submitted under the agreement, the project has been successfully implemented, achieving and surpassing "the majority of the development objectives" with e.g. a total of 173,000 women accessing improved delivery services in 25 districts as a result of the project. Below follows a summary of the main results as presented in the final report from the MoH.
Background The aim of the project was to increase facility-based deliveries and safe motherhood. Poor women were offered a voucher for UGX 4,000 UGX (about SEK 10), which covers four ante-natal care (ANC) visits, a delivery and one post-natal care (PNC) visit and from 2018 the voucher also includes post-partum family planning (PPFP) services. The women could choose whether to deliver at a public, private non-for-profit or private for-profit clinic. The facilities enrolled in the project were reimbursed for the services provided and clinic staff also received support in terms of capacity building through training and provision of medical equipment.
Summary of results
Provision of skilled delivery services - A total of 178,413 facility-based deliveries were supported by the project. This is an achievement of 114% against the project target of 156,400 and is a result of a slightly higher voucher redemption rate than anticipated (for delivery).
Antenatal and Post-natal care attendance - Cumulatively, the project distributed 231,002 vouchers out of which 193,658 (86%) were redeemed for at least one ANC visit. As expected, redemption for ANC1 was highest and subsequent visits reduced as follows; 80% (184,846) at ANC1, 67% (154,690) at ANC2, 54% (124,386) at ANC3, 34% (77,590) at ANC4. A total of 73,198 mothers attended postnatal care during the project period translating to an overall redemption rate of 41% following a significant increase from 36% in the second program year to 66% in the extension period). Post-Partum Family Planning registered an upward trend throughout the project from 10% in the second program year when the services were added to the voucher package to 39% in the project extension.
Capacity building - The project improved the capacity service providers to manage pregnancy and its complications as well as newborn care and Post-Partum Family Planning. This was done through trainings and mentorships and support supervision. Focus interventions were on 1) Technical competence 2) Clinical governance and infection prevention 3) Stock management. A total of 440 health workers were trained, mentored and their competences were assessed as level one. With support from the project, 23 health facilities, of which 82% (19) are public health facilities were upgraded to active Comprehensive Emergency Obstetric Care (CEmOC) facilities by functionalizing their operating theatres. The project contributed to strengthening of the supply chain for essential maternal health medicines and supplies in public facilities by complementing the existing National Medical Stores supply with an alternative source; the Joint Medical Stores. This intervention minimized stock outs of essential medicines and supplies in public health facilities thereby limiting unnecessary client referrals, incomplete treatments and compulsion of poor clients buy supplies.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
